titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: The Atlantic and Caribbean Steam Navigation Company, better known as the Red D Line was the main transportation link between the United States and Venezuela for 100 years. The company took its trade name from the red D on its white flag, which stood for (John) Dallett, a Philadelphia merchant who went to Venezuela in 1823 soon after the country gained its independence from Spain. There he went into business with the influential merchant John Boulton. Dallett returned to Philadelphia and set up a business shipping cargoes to Boulton, and in 1838 began chartering sailing vessels to carry his merchandise. The company built an excellent relationship with the Venezuelan government and business community, but eventually decided to get out of the shipping business when the 1936 Merchant Marine Act terminated the system of mail contracts under which shipping companies had been subsidized. The company was sold to the Grace Line in 1937, which then merged the Venezuelan operations into Grace's overall service to South America. http://www.theshipslist.com/ships/lines/redd.htm -- more detail supplied by a descendant of Dallett

scopecontent.p: Collection of records of the Atlantic and Caribbean Steam Navigation Company. Materials include: firms ledgers (1861-1871, 1881-1908); letter book for Red D Line (1872-1874), correspondence of Dallet, Bliss & Co, primarily with Henry Lord Boulton in Caracas; Atlantic and Caribbean Steam Navigation Co. trial balances (1881-1932); Dallet and Co's ledger, NY (1881-1909); Dallet family cash received (1862-18874); Clearance book (1861-1880); freight lists, various ships (1927-1932, 1932-1936), including weights of freight shipped to various South American ports. The collection also includes records of several vessels: barque Hornet, bills and expenses (1878), with several surveys of cargo damaged during storms; barque John Boulton, expense book (1870-1872); freight lists (1862-1875) for the brig A.B. Patterson and other vessels.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
